Blog.post: I have a mild case of sleep deprivation today. I stayed up until after 3 AM ("its 3AM, I must be lonely…") last night. Not sure why. I just could not get to sleep. To try to put myself to sleep, I foolishly started reading Return of the King , the last book in the urlLink Lord of the Rings trilogy. Silly me. I couldn't put it down! Luckily, I only had 60 or so pages before I finished. Phew! I could have been up all night. I digress - lack of sleep makes me tend to lose my concentration. I made a comment in the kitchen at work today that I wish I could take back. I owe it all to sleep deprivation. Someone was talking about how gross it was that someone put chicken bones in the garbage disposal. I uttered the first words that came to mind, "At least its not a human hand." What the…? Yes, it's true. The words went straight from my brain to my mouth without stopping in between to make sure it would be okay with me if it came out of my mouth. It even came out in a creepy, horror movie sort of voice. I need some sleep.

Cats are interesting animals. They lounge around the house all day, basking in the sunlight as it filters through the living room windows. They chase shadows (sometimes ceaselessly). Laser pointers fascinate them. One thing I find particularly interesting about cats is their reaction to Nepeta cataria L., aka catnip. Catnip, a member of the mint family, is a harmless "high" for felines. Although many cats will eat it, scientists say they're reacting to the smell rather than the taste. Felines bite, chew, rub against, and roll in catnip to release the volatile oil trapped in the leaves. Catnip is harvested when this essential oil production reaches its peak, and leaves and fragrant flowers are carefully air-dried to preserve essential oils at their best. About 80% of adult cats -- including lions, pumas, and leopards! -- react to this irresistible, intoxicating, analgesic soporific. The tendency to like or ignore catnip is inherited, and it's true that some cats are immune to its influence. Of particular interest is the fact that humans can use catnip, as well. Taken as a hot infusion, Catnip promotes sweating and is beneficial for colds, flus, fevers, and infectious childhood diseases. It is soothing to the nervous system and calming to the stomach. It aids with flatulence, diarrhea, and colic. It is sometimes used as an enema to cleanse and heal the lower bowel (use in diluted form). Catnip helps to prevent miscarriage and premature birth as well as allays morning sickness. So the next time the doctor suggests you get an enema, be sure to ask if he recommends catnip for the cleansing of your lower bowel area.

My youngest brother, Joshua (he's 15), recently bought a urlLink Hobie Cat sailboat off of urlLink eBay . This is no ordinary urlLink Sunfish sailboat, my friends. This is hardcore sailing. Here's the scoop. Joshua got involved in sailing a few years ago at the urging of some family friends. Since he was working for Dad last summer, he had some money saved up and decided to buy a sailboat. I guess he found this boat on eBay, and went ahead and bought it. The catch: the boat was in New Hampshire. Mom and Dad (and the rest of my family) live in Pennsylvania. South central Pennsylvania, to be a little more precise. The part of New Hampshire where the boat was located is approximately 13 hours away from my parents' house. Lucky for Joshua, our brother Jeremy was graduating from OIS on Saturday, so Mom and Dad would at least be in New England. Since they're such great parents, they agreed to drive up to New Hampshire from Newport, Rhode Island after Jeremy's graduation. Little did they know what was in store for them. After having lunch with Jeremy and Elizabeth after graduation, Mom and Dad followed me back to my house in the van, so we could drop my car off before heading up to pick up the boat. Perhaps I should give a little more detail about the van - it's my dad's work van. Its probably about 15 ft long (if that), and has only 2 seats. There were 3 of us riding in it. How do you fit 3 people in a van that has only two seats? It's known as a bucket seat, my friends. As in an empty five-gallon bucket turned upside-down. With a cushion on top. How comfortable! Normally, the trip from Boston to the area of New Hampshire to which we were traveling would take approximately 2 hours. We didn't take into account that half of the city of Boston travels to New Hampshire on Friday afternoon. Stop and go traffic is not fun, no matter which way you look at it. Its especially not fun on a make-shift bucket seat. When we finally reached our destination (a private lake in New Hampshire, right on the border with Maine), it was approximately 6:30, and it looked like rain. We didn't think the rain would be a big deal, since we didn't expect that it would be too hard to load the boat onto Dad's trailer. Riiiiight. This boat is 16 feet long with a 25 foot mast. At first Dad didn't think we'd be able to transport the thing. Period. Luckily Mom and I were able to talk him into it - Joshua would have been one unhappy teenager if they showed up in Pennsylvania without that urlLink Hobie Cat . If it weren't for Dad's van, and all of the tools that he had with him, there's no way in hell we could have taken that boat with us. The mast was lashed to one of the ladders Dad had on the roof rack. The pontoons were attached to the roof rack, as well. Thank goodness Dad also had the foresight to bring his 10 foot trailer with him. Without that, there's no way he could have carried the mast - it stuck out behind the truck approximately 8 feet, barely shorter than the length of the truck and trailer combined. The trampoline was then attached to the trailer. The whole process, from deciding whether or not we were even going to take the damned thing, to actually disassembling it and attaching each part to the truck or trailer, took a little over two hours. Oh, and did I mention the mosquitoes? Aside from the accommodations, the trip wasn't too bad. My parents are great to hang out with, and I haven't laughed that hard in a LONG time. Its amazing how cool your parents become after you move out of the house. The best part of the story, however, is that Joshua now has a kick ass boat. Oh yeah, I'd also like to mention that he paid $515 for a boat that would cost $7,500 new. That's a 93.1% discount!!

The world's largest flower, the Titan Arum, is blooming at the urlLink Quail Botanical Gardens in California. What is particularly interesting about this flower is its latin name - Amorphophallus titanum , which, loosely translated, means "giant shapeless phallus". One look at this urlLink flower , and you'll know how it got its name.

After he's done in Newport, he'll be heading to Washington, DC before he heads to Pittsburgh, PA for 6 months of training for his job with the Navy. He's going to be a nuclear propulsion engineer. Sorry, I can't help you - I don't know what it means, either. Let me give you a little bit of background on Jeremy. He spent 3 years at urlLink Shippensburg University in Shippensburg, PA. From there, he transferred to urlLink Penn State University in State College, PA. He graduated from both Penn State and Shippensburg this past May. His degree from Penn State is a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering. His degree from Shippensburg is a Bachelor of Science in Applied Physics. The receptionist in our office is one of the most incompetent people on the planet. She on vacation for two weeks, and in her absence, we employed a temp. The saying "You never know what you have until its gone" works in the other direction, as well - You never know what you don't have until you get it. Or something like that. At any rate, our receptionist sucks ! She has no working knowledge of computers. Period. I don't even know if she knows how to turn one on. She doesn't know how to empty the fax machine, either. Apparently that's someone else's job. I saw the chairman of the company looking for one of his faxes the other day. Hmmm... Isn't that generally viewed upon as being a job function of a receptionist? Not here!! Forget about ordering office supplies - we're better off walking a few blocks to Staples, picking out what we want, then submitting the receipt ourselves than asking her to order anything for us. Even if the item number is written out in block lettering, she still manages to fuck it up. Let's talk about the mail for a minute. The mail gets delivered around 10AM. It generally gets delivered to everyone's inbox between 3PM and 4PM. What is the delay here??? Its also rare for me to actually get my own mail. It usually belongs to someone in the office space across the hall. Getting my own mail was a delight last week with the wonderful temp (who, by the way, could generate labels in Word when asked). As defined by urlLink Webster's dictionary , the word receptionist is a noun that refers to a person employed to greet telephone callers, visitors, patients, or clients. In the literal sense of the word, this woman does a mediocre, at best, job. In the present day sense of the word, she's the worst I've ever seen.

Fellow urlLink Pi Nu ers, you will find the following particularly interesting, given its reference to a former Council member, and the fact that its the hometown of my former psycho roommate. Chad and Wendy, I think you might know who I mean here: PA BOROUGH HAS NO BAN ON BACKYARD BURIAL By Associated Press, 8/27/02 RED LION, Pa. — There's no law in this eastern Pennsylvania borough to prevent residents from burying dead loved ones in their backyards, and a local official wants to know if they want that to change. The borough council plans to discuss an ordinance that would prohibit human burials on property other than established cemeteries. The public will get a chance to comment on the proposal during a Sept. 9 meeting. Solicitor Michael Craley raised the idea of a home-burial ban. There is no state law prohibiting home burials but the state borough code does allow municipalities to ban the practice if they wish, he said. The borough has no law to regulate home burials in any way, zoning officer Lynn Rinehart said. Officials said they did not know how often home burials occur in the borough. P.S. I found this on urlLink Boston.com in the Odds & Ends section. Fitting, isn't it?

For those of you that don't have the unique pleasure of living in the city of Boston, The Improper Bostonian is a bi-weekly publication that highlights upcoming festivities, events, and general interesting goings-on in and around the city of Boston. I got a blast from the past earlier this week. Shauna Colegrove called me. All you urlLink Pi Nu ers out there may remember Shauna. She fell off the face of the earth somewhere around December 1999. Well, she's alive and well. She lives in Frederick, MD, and she found my cell phone number in an old address book of hers. I cannot express the shock at getting a phone call from her. Up until Wednesday night, I thought there was a distinct possibility that she really was MIA. As it turns out, she's working for Wells Fargo Home Mortgage, and is engaged to an alcoholic. Some things never change. While it was good to hear from her, I'm sorry to report that she's still the same old Shauna. Pretty much everyone that I keep in touch with from college has moved on from the small town mindset (regardless of whether they actually live in a small town), and have begun to function normally with the rest of the world. This is not the case with Shauna. She's the same as ever - same small-town mindset. Thank God I don't live in Shippensburg anymore.
I am going to fucking kill her. The Penguin has pushed too far this time. I should have strangled her in the ladies' room when I had the chance. The bitch must die.

In honor of the 20 year anniversary of the premier of Cheers , I have attached a list of Normisms, as found on urlLink Boston.com : A list of Normisms Coach: Can I draw you a beer, Norm? Norm: No, I know what they look like. Just pour me one. Coach: How about a beer, Norm? Norm: Hey I’m high on life, Coach. Of course, Beer is my life. Coach: How’s a beer sound, Norm? Norm: I Dunno. I usually finish them before they get a word in. Coach: What’s up, Norm? Norm: Corners of my mouth, Coach. Coach: What’s shaking, Norm? Norm: All four cheeks and a couple of chins, Coach. Coach: Beer, Normie? Norm: Uh, Coach, I dunno, I had one this week. Eh, why not, I’m still young. Coach: Normie, Normie, would this be Vera? Norm: With a lot of expensive surgery, maybe. Coach: What’s up, Normie? Norm: The temperature under my collar, Coach. Coach: What would you say to a nice beer, Normie? Norm: Going down? Coach: What’s up, Norm? Norm: Everything that’s supposed to be. Sam: What’s new, Normie? Norm: Terrorists, Sam. They’ve taken over my stomach. They’re demanding beer. Coach: What would you say to a beer, Normie? Norm: Daddy wuvs you. Sam: What’d you like, Normie? Norm: A reason to live. Gimme another beer. Sam: What will you have, Norm? Norm: Well, I’m in a gambling mood, Sammy. I’ll take a glass of whatever comes out of that tap. Sam: Oh, Looks like beer, Norm. Norm: Call me Mister Lucky. Sam: What do you say, Norm? Norm: Any Cheap, tawdry thing that’ll get me a beer. Sam: What do you say to a beer, Normie? Norm: Hiya, Sailor. New in town? Sam: Whaddya say, Norm? Norm: Well, I never met a beer I didn’t drink. And down it goes. Woody: What’s your pleasure, Mr. Peterson? Norm: Boxer shorts and loose shoes. But I’ll settle for a beer. Paul: Hey Norm, how’s the world been treating you? Norm: Like a baby treats a diaper. Norm: Hey, everybody. Woody: Norm! (Nobody else in the room says anything) Norm: That’s it, I’m leaving. Sam: How’s life treating you? Norm: It’s not, Sammy, but you can! Woody: Can I pour you a draft, Mr. Peterson? Norm: A little early, isn’t it Woody? Woody: For a beer? Norm: No, for stupid questions. Woody: Hey, Mr. Peterson, there’s a cold one waiting for you. Norm: I Know, and is she calls, I’m not here. Sam: Whatcha up to Norm? Norm: My ideal weight if I were eleven feet tall.

This just in: Nation gets free tacos if Taco Bell target is hit By Associated Press, 10/22/02 SAN FRANCISCO -- Barry Bonds could end up feeding the nation during this World Series. Taco Bell is promising free tacos for the entire country if Bonds, or any other player, hits a target floating in a cove behind the right-field fence at Pacific Bell Park. The 15-foot diameter target will remain in place through Game 5. Any home run that touches it during the three games scheduled at the park entitles everyone in the United States to a free taco coupon. The company says it would pick a window of time on one day when people can redeem the coupons. Of the 27 home runs to land in McCovey Cove since the park opened, Bonds has hit 21 of them for the San Francisco Giants. His team faces the Anaheim Angels on Tuesday in Game 3. Taco Bell sponsored a similar promotion last year, offering free tacos to the country if the Mir space station hit the company's 40-foot-by-40-foot target in the South Pacific. Mir finished the day 0-1.

Here’s a log of what I did today: 3:00AM Wake up in a panic, thinking Mom & Dad have overslept, and I’m going to miss my flight back to Boston. 3:15AM Realize that I’m mistaken in thinking everyone overslept, but now I can’t get back to sleep. 3:23AM Check online to see if my flight is on time. According to the urlLink US Airways website , everything is on time. 4:38AM Dad and I make our first attempt to head to the airport, but are stopped short in our tracks due to the large amount of snow in the driveway. 4:39AM Dad gets some wood ashes from the wood stove, and Voila! : we have made it out of the driveway. 4:40AM to 5:20AM Every muscle in my body is tensed up as Dad and I try not to get stuck in any snow drifts, and at the same time avoid oncoming traffic in the middle of a white out. You’d be surprised how many people are on the road at that time of day. 5:21AM We get on the PA turnpike, and its like a different world – do they heat that road or something? There was absolutely NO snow to be seen on the road. Anywhere. 6:05AM Arrive at Harrisburg International Airport (which, by the way, is the smallest international airport I’ve ever seen. Its international because they have airlines that fly to Canada from there…). 6:07AM Attempt to check in at the US Airways E-Ticket Check-In Kiosk. 6:07AM and 11 seconds Attempt to check in at the US Airways E-Ticket Check-In Kiosk fails because the flight that was still on schedule at 3:23AM has since been cancelled . 6:30AM Get checked in for a flight to Boston by way of La Guardia. Apparently that flight was delayed for an hour (should have left at 6:10) due to one of the crew being stuck in the snow. 7:20AM Depart for La Guardia. The connecting flight to Boston doesn’t leave New York until 10AM. Plenty of time. Right. I'll give you the rest of the story later....

Found on urlLink Yahoo! : Swingers Club Shut Because Moaning Too Loud BERLIN (Reuters) - A swingers club in Berlin has been forced to shut because a court ruled that members' moans and shrieks of pleasure broke noise regulations. Partner-swapping customers at the ground-floor club called "Zwielicht" -- a German word meaning both "twilight" and "dubious" -- upset those living upstairs, a Berlin court ruled this week. "There are other clubs and brothels in this area and the customers there don't make so much noise. They are more discreet," a court spokeswoman said Wednesday. An additional problem was that Zwielicht offered a limousine service to ferry its members to and from affiliated clubs. "Cars came and went, doors were slammed and people talked loudly outside on the street," the spokeswoman said. Berlin actress Anouschka Renzi, who lives above the club, told the court she was tired of seeing men wearing only bathrobes getting out of limousines on their way into the club. "This is not a red-light district," she said. Shit. There goes my vacation getaway for the spring!!

Here are some fun facts about how the avocado industry benefits from the Superbowl. All statistics provided by the good folks at urlLink FoxSports : Some facts about avocados Just off a stretch of Southern California interstate called the Avocado Highway, work crews in the U.S. avocado capital are harvesting fist-sized fruits destined to be mashed and mixed by football fans across the country. Super Bowl Sunday has become one of the biggest days for U.S. avocado consumption as the popularity of its zesty dip derivative, guacamole, has spread. Here are some little known facts about avocadoes ... • California supplies 86 percent of U.S.-grown avocados. • San Diego County supplies 46 percent of California-grown avocados. • Most California avocados are harvested on 60,000 acres between San Luis Obispo and the Mexican border. • An estimated 40 million pounds of avocados will be eaten during Super Bowl-related festivities. • Avocados are consumed in nearly 45 percent of U.S. homes; in the West the portion is 80 percent. • Seven varieties of avocado are grown in California, with Hass avocados making up 85 percent of the volume. • Avocados belong to the genus Persea, a member of the Lauraceae family. For more information about avocados, go to urlLink Avocados.org .

To try and win back the respect and admiration of all 2 of my readers, here's some distressing news about my favorite source of urlLink potassium : Bananas' Days May Be Numbered, Scientist Says Wed Jan 15, 3:34 PM ET LONDON (Reuters) - It is one of the world's favorite fruits, but the banana hasn't had sex in years and its days may be are numbered. Without scientific help the sterile, seedless fruit could disappear with 10 years, according to a Belgian plant pathologist. Emile Frison, the head of the International Network for the Improvement of Banana and Plantain in Monpellier, France, said the fruit lacks the genetic diversity to fight off diseases and pests that are plaguing banana plantations and only biotechnology and genetic manipulation may be able to save it. "Frison sees it as the only hope for the banana," New Scientist said on Wednesday. "Without assistance banana production could drop and mark the beginning of the end of the fruit." "We may even see the extinction of the banana as both a lifesaver for hungry and impoverished Africans and as the most popular product on the world's supermarket shelves," the magazine added.

I hope everyone had a great New Year’s celebration! Becki (old roommate) and her boyfriend Phil were here, and we had a lot of fun. As usual on New Year's Eve, I got way too drunk, and don't remember much of what happened after we left Michi's (Boston friend) place. 5 of us left her apartment around 11:15 to go to Boston Harbor to see the fireworks in the fog. It was fun, and I was incredibly intoxicated... Becki tells me I kissed some guy with a video camera, and on the bus on the way home, I had a conversation with some Israeli guy about nuclear armament in North Korea. Oh yeah, and I tried to give some Irish guys egg nog on the subway. So now I'm trying to figure out why I act like such a jackass when I get severely intoxicated. Granted, much of the greater population act like jackasses when they get as intoxicated as I was, but this has only started happening to me over the past few years. I guess it didn't start until after I graduated from college. I used to be this happy-go-lucky drunk that would make people laugh with my silliness, rather than make people stare in shock with my bitterness, and mean, nasty comments. I think I pissed off half of the people at Michi's house, because I was just being cruel. While I was recovering from my hangover yesterday, I was pondering this change for the worse, and I think I've discovered the answer: I'm angry. I don't know why I'm angry, and I don't think I'm angry at anyone in particular. I've just become an angry person. I guess the next step is to try to figure out why I've gotten like this, and then try to fix it. So I guess now I’ve found my New Year’s resolution: Get back to the June of the mid-to-late-90s. I’ll let you know how it works out.

Well, its 1 AM, and for the fourth night in a row, I'm not able to get to sleep before 12:30. Does anyone have any suggestions to help me sleep? Beer just isn't working. I'm on my third Rolling Rock of the evening. I think its this damned new computer I bought. I get home from work and immediately jump on this thing, log on to the internet (to chat with ex-boyfriends - v. bad idea!) or continue to do work that I didn't feel like finishing at the office. Am becoming a workoholic. That's not necessarily a bad thing. Can you tell I'm reading Bridget Jones ? Note the bad grammar and excessive use of 'v's when describing things. I'm going on a road trip tomorrow. Alas, I'll be making yet another trip southbound alone. I kind of like driving by myself. It gives me lots of time to just think. When I'm not shouting at other drivers, that is. I really can't get over how many bad drivers there are out there. I like to think of myself as a defensive driver. That's not to say that I'm an asshole on the road - quite the contrary, in fact. I'm constantly on the alert for what I like to call The Butthole Drivers. Those who drive around with their heads up their ass. There's a whole hell of a lot of them out there. If they don't live in Massachusetts, they live in New Jersey. I hate New Jersey. As far as I'm concerned, the only good thing that ever came out of New Jersey was Bon Jovi. And my friend Kristen's husband. That's about it. Speaking of Kristen, one of the reasons I'm taking this road trip is to head to College Park, MD (yes, Wendy, the home of the horrible Terps) to help Kristen celebrate her 26th birthday. Friend Becky (not to be confused with Cousin Becky and Roommate Becki) and I are going to hang out with the Miller (that's Kristen) in Maryland tomorrow - or rather tonight - night. Should be a good time. The last time just the three of us went out was... Shit - I can't remember when. I have a great picture of the three of us at Kristen's bachelorette party in NYC. That was 3 years ago. WOW! Anyhow, should be a good time. Perhaps now would be a good time to attempt to differentiate between the Becky(i)s. - Cousin Becky is my second cousin on my father's side. She's been married for (*gasp*) almost two years. She and her husband Joshua live in Indianapolis and are expecting their first child in the beginning of May. She and our second cousin Sara and I were pretty much the best of friends while we were growing up. Cousin Becky was born six months before Sara and Sara was born six months before me. Cousin Becky used to call me Little Baby June when we were little. High school was a lot of fun. If you ever meet Cousin Becky or Sara, be sure to ask them about the time we all watched Untamed Heart with Christian Slater and Marisa Tomei. All I have to say is - he gave her the records *sniff, sniff*! - Friend Becky has been a good friend since we sat next to each other in Mrs. Ebersole's English class in 8th grade. She once wrote me a note during study hall that was all pictures. Each picture represented a word - the first letter of that word was a letter in the word that she was writing. For example, the word 'shit' would have been represented by a sheep, a house, an igloo and a turtle. Very complex and rather confusing. You can imagine how much fun it is to hang out with Friend Becky. She is now married with two children, and lives in Fayetteville - she didn't stray too far from home. - Roommate Becki is the Becki that spells her name with an 'i' - obviously. She and I met while I was working for Financial Trust (which then became Keystone Financial which then became M&T Bank - bastards) in the Shippensburg Office. The first time we worked together was the week before Spring Fest 1997. We became fast friends after that, and the rest is history. Some of my favorite memories with Roommate Becki happened while we were living together in a kickass apartment on the corner of Prince and Orange Streets in Shitten - I mean Shippensburg. We used to go out to the bars together, stumble home at different times, and when one of us woke up, we'd stumble into the other's room, fall on the bed, and try to remember what happened the night before. This was an almost nightly practice. Ah, the good old days. Here's a tidbit - I'm 47 days older than Roommate Becki. During this road trip, I'll get to hang out with Friend Becky on Friday night, Cousin Becky on Saturday afternoon for her baby shower, and Roommate Becki on Sunday afternoon at the mini birthday celebration my parents are holding for me. In case you were curious, my 25th birthday is on the 29th of March. Be sure to mark your calendars. On top of the fact that my car insurance rates will drop, I'll also be able to rent a car hassle free. WOO-HOO! I think I'll call this weekend The Weekend of the Becky(i)s. I'm planning on having a blast. Okay - 20 minutes later, I've written one heck of a long blog entry. Don't look for too many more of these random entries - unless this insomnia continues.

In looking over the last several blog entries that I have posted, it occurred to me that I never really put any “real” content in my postings. Generally, I just post links to all of the urlLink crazy shit that I find on the internet. My hope is that sometimes the urlLink two people that read urlLink this at least find the links here interesting and, dare I say, even urlLink educational . That being said, I figured you guys are due for an update on what’s going on with me for a change. Let’s see – where to begin? Well, since moving to Boston in October of 2000 to start a new life outside of Pennsylvania, I have managed to earn a 33.8% salary increase. Not too bad, eh? I started out as a portfolio accountant for a small wealth management firm situated in downtown Boston, and have worked my way into the operations department, where my official title is now Manager of Accounting Systems. Basically, I’m the office computer geek. There are only 31 employees in the entire company. Being the youngest - and most computer savvy, when we purchased a new software package, I took over the job of making sure it works properly. That has since ballooned into this whole other position (I’m pretty much the operations guru here), which I love . Maybe I should have been an urlLink MIS major in urlLink college . Outside of work, I have amassed a group of friends that I hang out with on a pretty regular basis. On Tuesday nights we go to urlLink karaoke at the urlLink Milky Way in Jamaica Plain. Although JP can be scary at times (in fact, one of my friends got assaulted in the parking lot one night – they caught the girl that attacked her, and she’s currently tied up in the Massachusetts court system), we have a blast there. On the weekends, we usually end up drinking urlLink cheap beer until all hours of the night. When I’m not hanging out with the gang, I’m usually playing handbells, the baritone, or singing in the choir at urlLink Newton Presbyterian Church . Its been great getting back into music again! Although, in keeping with tradition, I never practice my baritone, even though I should. As far as the boyfriend scene goes, I’m not going there – its so pathetic, its really just sad… So that, in a nutshell, is what’s been happening with me, my friends! I skipped a lot of the details, but I’ll fill them in as I go along. If I start to stray from keeping you up to date on what’s going on, just shoot me an email and let me know.

urlLink Weird : Third child born on 3/3/03 at 3:33 p.m. By Associated Press, 3/6/03 FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. -- Good things came in threes for a Florida Panhandle mother. Samantha Noble gave birth to her third child on Monday, March 3 -- that's 3-3-03 -- at exactly 3:33 p.m. Dean Noble weighed in a 7 pounds, 2 ounces. He was 19 inches long. "When I had my first ultrasound, I remember thinking, 'This better not be triplets,"' his mother said. "The threes have to stop sometime." She said her husband, Aaron, joked about having the child at 3:33 p.m. when he brought her to Fort Walton Beach Medical Center. "I told him, 'No, I don't want to wait that long,"' she said. Although baby Dean's two siblings, ages 8 and 3, had complications at birth, he appears to be healthy. "This is the first time I might be able to leave with a perfectly healthy baby," Samantha Noble said. "Three might be lucky after all."

True Friends Over the past month, it has become apparent who my true friends are. About a month ago, I found out that my best friend in Boston slept with the guy that I had been dating. I'll give you a second to let that sink in. One Saturday night in mid-May Rob walked out on me when we were having a discussion about our relationship. Since we'd been drinking he decided he'd better not drive all the way back to his house in Salem. So he drove to Denise's apartment. No clue why. He'd only met her a handful of times, and it still baffles me how he even knew how to get to her house (for those of you who have ever tried to give driving directions to anywhere in Boston, you know how confusing things can be). After Denise hid everything from me for a week, one of Rob's friends ended up telling me what happened. I was floored. When Shana first told me, I told her that Rob must have been lying. Then she started giving me details of when they had met up again after the first time Saturday night. There's no way he could have known her schedule without talking to her. Then the shock set in. I didn't really sleep the night I found out. It was Memorial Day weekend, and we were having a Memorial Day/Going Away party for Martha (my roommate who just moved out) and Shana (she moved to Arizona) the next day. Denise, of course, was supposed to be at the party, but after getting the news, I didn't want her anywhere near me. Wouldn't you know it, she had all of the beer for the party in the trunk of her car. So I asked her to come over early so we could let the beer chill. As she was getting ready to leave to change for the party, I confronted her. I told her that I knew what had happened. She was pretty surprised, to say the least. Then I asked her not to come back. My friends were great about everything. They were just as shocked as I was to find out what had happened. None of them really liked Rob to begin with, but they certainly never expected Denise to behave this way. She really fucked up, though. When she messed with me, she messed with my entire group of friends. They've been so amazing - incredibly supportive, and very willing to listen when I needed to vent. I think they've been taking turns calling to check up on me. I'm so lucky to have such great friends that I can count on! I ended up meeting up with Denise about 3 weeks after everything happened. She said she never expected to hear from me again. We hashed things out, and after everything was said, I told her that I can't forgive her for what she's done, and that we can no longer be friends. I also told her that Boston's a relatively small town, and if she continues to see him and I see them together somewhere, I'll slap him if I'm within range. And a week after I found out about what happened, Martha moved out. For those of you keeping count, that means that within a matter of one week, I lost 3 people - the jackass I was dating, my best friend in Boston, and my awesome roommate Martha. So, yeah. I'm looking forward to urlLink vacation next week.

Barbeques Before and since Martha's moving out, I've been cooking a lot of meals on the grill. I love the grill. There's nothing like the taste of a nice juicy burger fresh off the grill. My dad showed me how to grill up potatoes that last time I was home. I'm talking about whole potatoes here. Just get some Crisco, urlLink a bag of potatoes , and a flame. Lather up the potato in some urlLink Crisco , throw it on the flame for 30-50 minutes (depending on the size of the potato), and you've got yourself a true delicacy. Now the secret to a good burger is to get some urlLink ground beef that's approximately 75% lean/25% fat. You're not going to get a nice juicy burger with much less fat than that. And be sure to get ground beef - not the pre-made burgers. Its much more fun to pack them yourself. The next ingredient to a successful night of grilling: vegetables. My personal favorite is urlLink grilled red peppers . Marinate them in a little bit of olive oil and balsamic vinegar, topped off with a dash or two of oregano and basil. Mmm, mmm, mmm. D-licious! Of course, the last ingredient to a successful barbeque is urlLink beer . But then again, I didn't need to tell you that, did I? It seems as though my house is going to be BBQ central this summer. Look for urlLink pictures later this summer.

I have developed an especially nasty cold over the weekend. One guy in the brass group I perform with said it could be SARS. I could've killed him. So I did a Google search on SARS symptoms. That took me to the urlLink WHO website . Here's what I found: As more information has become available, WHO-recommended SARS case definitions have been revised as follows: Suspect Case A person presenting after 1 February 2003 with history of : high fever (>38oC) AND one or more respiratory symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, difficulty breathing close contact* with a person who has been diagnosed with SARS recent history of travel to areas reporting cases of SARS Probable Case A suspect case with chest x-ray findings of pneumonia or Respiratory Distress Syndrome OR A person with an unexplained respiratory illness resulting in death (!) , with an autopsy examination demonstrating the pathology of Respiratory Distress Syndrome without an identifiable cause. Comments In addition to fever and respiratory symptoms, SARS may be associated with other symptoms including: headache, muscular stiffness, loss of appetite, malaise, confusion, rash, and diarrhea. That little bit about the unexplained respiratory illness resulting in death doesn't make me feel too good. Although, the article that I pulled this data from is nearly 3 months old. In any event, I have a stuffy head and a sore back from coughing so much. On top of that, my right ear hurts. I'm prone to infections in my right ear... Looks like I'll be making a trip to the doctor tomorrow in lieu of going to work. At this point, I'd much rather have to go to work than have to go to the doctor.

On my way to urlLink karaoke tonight, I could've sworn I saw urlLink Mars ! I was driving down Washington St., and as I crossed Beacon St. in Brookline, I happened to look up and saw a big red object in the sky. Having read a good bit about Mars and its rather close proximity to Earth right now, I couldn't help but get excited at how cool it was that I was looking at Mars!! While I was at work today, I was reading some articles online about how it's so close right now that you can actually make out the ice cap and some rough terrain with the aid of a simple telescope. And sure enough, I could see the white ice cap blaring against the redness of the Red Planet. I could hardly wait to get to the bar and tell my friends to come out and look at this thing! We were going to be witnessing history. Mars hasn't been this close to Earth since, well, a hell of a long time ago! But then I was thinking - I know Mars is close right now, but this thing looks like its even closer than the Moon!! The object was sort of half-moon shaped, and I thought, Wow - Earth must be between Mars and the Sun right now! This is so cool ! And then I got closer. And closer. I kept looking up at the sky, and as I was approaching Huntington Ave., it became clear to me. It was a blimp. A red fucking blimp. A red SATURN blimp. As in the car. Definitely not Mars. And the ice cap I could've sworn I saw? The big while lettering spelling out Saturn. I was humiliated. Thank goodness no one else was in the car with me. Isn't it ironic, though? I thought I was looking at Mars and it was a Saturn blimp. That settles it - I'm a geek.

Here's a theory for you to ponder: The cleanliness of my room is directly related to my ability to get out of bed and get to work on time. I have become an urlLink Alias junkie. Courtesy of urlLink Netflix , I have been watching the complete first season on DVD. Now when I say I've been watching, we're talking marathon sessions here. I watched the first seven hours of the first season last Monday night. I popped in the first DVD when I got home from work, and the only time I stopped was in between episodes when I needed to change the laundry from the washer to the dryer and start a new load in the washer. We're talking addiction here. I think part of the reason I'm so addicted is because I'm going to become Sydney Bristow someday. Someday soon. I can feel it. International spies everywhere will fear me. Some dashing young CIA agent is going to fall in love with me and we will live life happily ever after. At least until everyone thinks I'm dead for 2 years. Okay, so maybe I don't want to be a secret double agent. But something around here definitely needs to change. I'm getting bored.

Hiya, kids!! I'm writing from New York City, where I'm attending the urlLink Advent Users Conference . Advent is a software firm that specializes in client reporting, among other things. I just spent a night out with Advent Users Group members, and a myriad of Advent employees. As always, it was a good time. I'm very much looking forward to a wedding this weekend in Manhattan. In general, though, I avoid politics and religion like the plague - I've witnessed way too many family arguments to go down that road... Any and all comments welcome!

What exactly is the point of reporting on a urlLink top secret rocket ? On a different note, there was some domestic excitement at my house last night. There's been a rather vile stench emanating from the refrigerator for the last several days. I'd removed all of the potentially spoiled food/condiments/etc. from the fridge late last week to no avail. So last night I pumped the cleaning music (read the hardcore stuff), rolled up my sleeves and dug in. After removing the entire remaining contents of the refrigerator, cleaning the door, and both racks inside, I moved down to the storage drawers in the bottom. After I removed the first one, I knew I was in trouble. There was a puddle of murky looking water festering under the drawer. After I removed the second drawer, the vile stench intensified. I had found the source of the stench. The murky pool of festering water was stinking up the entire kitchen. I cleaned it up, then called the landlord who promptly said, I'll have a new one over there tomorrow. He wasn't kidding. He showed up at my door at 8:15 this morning with a brand spanking new refrigerator. We plan to have a memorial service for the 42 year-old refrigerator that's been serving our needs for the last 3 years. This past weekend a gang of us urlLink took on Mt. Monadnock . The trip was not uneventful. Snyder got locked out of his apartment by his idiot roommate, which started a chain reaction of events. We ended up leaving about an hour later than we anticipated. In northern Mass, we witnessed a car accident right in front of us (some dude in his mid-life crisis convertible cut off the lady in front of me (who'd cut me off about 15 minutes before) - we barely missed rear-ending her in the process). Jesse called 911, and we hightailed it out of there so we wouldn't be detained any further. After we got done with our jaunt up the mountain, we headed towards TGIFriday's in Nashua only to discover that it wasn't there anymore. We then decided on Ruby Tuesday's, but no one could figure out how to get into the parking lot. After three attempts, we finally made it. We got back to Boston around 10, and Snyder's dumb roommate's car was in the driveway, but not at home. He finally got ahold of the dolt and got into his apartment around 11:45.... All in all it was a great weekend!

I don't want to talk about it. From the urlLink Boston Globe : And so a new generation of New Englanders has learned the risk of rooting for the Red Sox. They will make you believe this really is the year. But in the end, they will fall and sometimes they will do it in excruciating fashion.

Ahhh.... A moment's peace. I went home over Columbus Day weekend and got to meet the newest member of my extended family. My cousin Becky and her husband came home from Indianapolis with their 5-month old son. He's such a good baby!! I then got to spend the weekend in my hometown of Chambersburg. What a small town. The first place I visited Friday morning was the florist. I saw one of the minister's from my church in there, and we chit-chatted a bit. Next stop, Rite Aid. I needed a toothbrush (I'd forgotten mine) and some batteries for my digital camera. In there I ran into one of my cousins and her sick daughter - they were picking up a prescription. Next stop, Grandma and Pap-pap's. As I was getting out of the car at their house, the minister I had seen at the florist's was waiting at the stoplight by Grandma's house. She beeped and asked that I say, "Hi" to my grandmother for her (Grandma broke her ankle about 2 months ago). Talk about a small town. The weekend was a blast, though. My brother Jason was up for homecoming king last weekend. He got first runner-up. The kid that won king was part of a legacy, though. His father was homecoming king in 1970 at his high school, and his older brother was king 4 years ago. I think it was rigged. I spent Saturday morning with my mom and sister. We made a trip to urlLink Aldi's . For those of you not in the know, Aldi's is a grocery store that is more than just a grocery store. My mother and I purchased very comfortable slippers there this weekend. This was the first time I ever had the pleasure of shopping urlLink there , and I was rather surprised at the ingenuity of this: Not only does it make carts available at all times and keeps the parking lot shopping-cart-free, but they don't have to employ anyone to retrieve the carts, thereby saving money!! I got an action shot of my sister getting her quarter back after returning the cart: We actually pissed off some locals in getting this picture. A woman and her husband ran up to us with a quarter in her outstretched hand. She wanted to trade us a quarter for the cart. Jessica said, "Sorry. My sister wants to get a picture of me returning the cart and getting the quarter back." We got some weird looks for that one. That afternoon we hung out at my aunt and uncle's new house. Dad, Jess and I were putting some protective stain on the outside of the house. Jess got a shot of me hard at work: Sunday was a gorgeous day, and I valked around in ze voods with Mom and Dad, taking a few pictures along the way. While on the Mass Pike on the way back to Boston on Monday, Christin called me and informed me of a very interesting conversation she had just had with our landlord. It turns out that the guys upstairs are moving out at the end of December (one of them bought a house in Weston and the other one is getting married). The landlord and his wife have decided they want to convert this house into a one-family house and move their family in here. The sooner, the better. So they've offered us a pretty sweet deal, and we found a new place to live about a mile and a half away from here. We'll be a block from the T, and within walking distance to some of my friends' apartments. We'll be moving either November 16 or December 1. And now it's time to watch the Red Sox beat the Yankees for the AL pennant.

Okay, still alive here, but there's lots going on. Christin and I are being forced to find a new apartment, which we have, the Red Sox are still fighting for the American League pennant, and Martha passed her bar exam. Lots more to tell when I have more time. Cheers!

One of my best friends from home has been married for about three and a half years now. When they got married, she decided not to take his name, as she and her sister are the only children in her father's side of the family. Thus, the family name dies out. I didn't realize that situations like this are occuring all over the place. An urlLink interesting article on FoxNews.com points out various ways to share names with your spouse. In my friend's case, she kept her last name, while he assumed her last name as a second middle name. An interesting approach - I remember her saying that he was going to drop it again because it was too confusing to explain to people. As for me, who knows if I'll assume Mr. Right's last name? My first goal is to find Mr. Right - the rest is just details...

From the urlLink Weather Channel : A break for the Northeast tomorrow Sun., Dec. 7, 2003 2:11 P.M. Buzz Bernard, Sr. Meteorologist, The Weather Channel Northeast Most of New England this afternoon looks something akin to what you'd see on Donner Summit or Snoqualmie Pass after a big snow in the Sierras or Cascades. (Where are the rotary plows when you need them?) The good news for tomorrow is that this historic December siege will be over and recovery can forge ahead. Winds will abate over New England, and throughout the region temperatures will rally after a very cold morning. Highs are expected to range from the 20s over northern New England and eastern New York to the 40s south of Baltimore. Best to take advantage of the relatively benign conditions Monday to clean off roofs, gutters and drains, for heavy rain--yes, rain--looms for Wednesday night and Thursday. The rain, in turn, will be followed by another shot of frigid air, and the landscape will morph to a polar ice cap. Ah, the joys of a Northeastern winter. I heard on the news today that this was the second largest December snow storm in Boston history.

Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow... I spent the greater part of yesterday watching the extended versions of The Fellowship of the Ring and The Two Towers at Michi's house. Luckily for me, I now live within walking distance of her apartment! On the way home last night, I took urlLink pictures of the white stuff that had fallen. Took urlLink some more this morning , too. Thankfully, we're a lot closer to the T here, so I'm not too concerned about shoveling out my car right now. Nevertheless, Michi and I took an interesting trip to the hardware store this afternoon to pick up some shovels. Apparently the rest of Brighton had the same idea. We had to go to two different stores before we found any - they were all sold out in the first store. Out of all the shots I got from this storm, here's my favorite (taken at the corner of Comm Ave. and Colborne Rd.):

Holy fucking shit. The long arm of Old Man Winter touched down on the greater Boston area this morning. I awoke to a light dusting of snow outside my window, which was a pleasant surprise. At least it was pleasant for me - I don't have to drive to work, or even worry too much about traffic anymore, since my move. I just take the T into town (even though it's the dreaded B line, at least I know that it's going to take me 50 minutes to get into work everyday, rather than the unpredictability of the Mass Pike). Areas north and west of the city had traffic backed up for miles . One of my co-workers lives 17 miles northwest of Boston. It took him two and a half hours to drive in this morning. Another gentleman who works here rolled in about 5 minutes ago - he lives 21 miles north of the city. Even pedestrians are feeling it - I watched some poor guy lose it just outside the Park Street T station this morning. His feet went right out from under him and he landed on his back on a nice patch of black ice. He sort of laid there with his arms outstretched and offered some advice for the rest of us: Watch the ice there. It's a bit slippery. Enjoy your day, folks.

This week's (and my first) urlLink Friday Five : You have just won one million dollars: 1. Who do you call first? My mom - I always call her first 2. What is the first thing you buy for yourself? Lunch - at the Ritz Carlton - followed quickly by the purchase of a new car 3. What is the first thing you buy for someone else? A new car for my sister and my two youngest brothers (one for each) and a new car for Dad, too 4. Do you give any away? If yes, to whom? urlLink Pi Nu , urlLink Shippensburg University , and probably the urlLink American Diabetes Association 5. Do you invest any? If so, how? Given I work in the industry, I'd probably get fired if I didn't invest. That being said, I'd probably have my advisor invest 60% in aggresive growth securities, 35% in a mix of large cap equities and fixed income securities, and the remaining 5% in goverment bonds. Okay, okay - so most of those answers are pretty boring. Here's hoping for some fun questions next week!

The weather over the past 5 days has been more than frigid. The low on Friday night was -3 degrees. That's in Fahrenheit, not Celsius. The urlLink forecast for this coming week: The coldest air in nearly two decades is likely to affect Southern New England Wednesday into early Friday then May release rapidly over the weekend This past Friday and Saturdays weather May have been just a taste of what is likely to be a more severe onslaught of frigid record cold. Snow early tomorrow will probably interfere with the morning commute. Then an arctic cold front will drill scattered snow showers and flurries through Southern New England late Tuesday or Tuesday evening on gale force wind gusts. Wednesday Will find temperatures hovering near zero with chill similar to that of this past Friday and Saturday. Conditions are likely to worsen late Thursday with numbing cold wind chills of 25 to 30 below zero and record cold temperatures of 5 to 15 below for much of the area. Even the Cape and Nantucket should see temperatures drop to near zero or even just a bit below. Snow occurring tonight and then possibly again Thursday will make it easier for the cold to penetrate to the south coast, but even if a coastal storm were to miss to the south, this weather pattern will deliver a harsh reminder of what its like to live in the more northerly latitudes. This coastal development Thursday May add to the winter rigors, especially along the south coast, where several hours of significant accumulations are possible. The track of this storm is much less certain than the shot of oncoming cold. As that intensifying storm passes to our east, we will feel its blustery effects Thursday night into Friday. Temperatures will recover this weekend as the core of this frigid airmass shifts east of New England. Heating system and car batteries as well as plumbing systems that are not in good working order and not properly insulated from the Cold May be victim of this 3 day period of excessive cold. Please stay tuned for updated statements on the upcoming cold, strong wind and possible snows. If you haven't already broken out the longjohns, you might want to.

After stressing about it for a week (and staring at a steadily growing pile of laundry), Christin and I went down to the basement this morning in an attempt to fix the washing machine. New Year's Eve was interesting, as always. This is the first year since I moved up here that I didn't have anyone visiting to ring in the new year. It's a good thing, too. Usually, much alcohol is imbibed immediately upon my return home from work. Then I generally stumble to a party where I make an ass of myself, and leave just in time to make it to Boston Harbor for the fireworks. urlLink Last year , on the way home from the harbor, I struck up a conversation with an Israeli man on the bus - about nuclear armament in North Korea. This year, however, I came home from work and took a nap. Around 8:30, Christin and I headed out to the two parties where we planned to make an appearance. As an aside here, can I just tell you how nice it is to live within walking distance of my friends? Back to the story. The first party was at my friend's boyfriend's apartment. As we were the first people there, it was a little awkward at first, but urlLink Rolling Rock always helps out in those situations. After some pleasant conversation, we decided to head up the street to Michi's house before we got too intoxicated (with our empty stomachs, and all - in hindsight, we probably should have eaten dinner). We arove at Michi's around 10:15, and I finished the 6-pack of urlLink Bud Light that I brought before midnight. With no one to kiss at midnight, I decided to guzzle on a glass of urlLink Old New England Egg Nog . The details are a bit hazy after the egg nog started flowing. I remember talking to a guy whose last name was Weed. And his birthday is April 20. I shit you not. I actually looked at his driver's license to confirm. At least I think I did.

From urlLink FoxNews.com : Barbie and Ken: It's Over Thursday, February 12, 2004 By Catherine Donaldson-Evans NEW YORK — One of America's most famous couples is calling it quits. Are you sitting down? After 43 years together, Barbie and Ken — as in the dolls — have decided that breaking up is hard to do, but do it they must. Since they're dolls — and famous — Barbie and Ken had no direct comment about their split at the International Toy Fair, where the bombshell was dropped. The news predictably came from their spokespeople during a press conference Thursday. "This is an announcement we thought we’d never make," said Barbie’s publicist, Ken Sunshine. "I will confirm that Ken and Barbie are going to go their separate ways." The circumstances surrounding the famous couple's break were hazy, though their spokespeople assured the press they split up on good terms. "The flame of love has gone out," said Ken's publicist, A. Russell Arons — who doubles as Mattel Inc.'s vice president of marketing for Barbie. "The tolls of Hollywood romance are well known." Arons and Sunshine described it as a "sad" and "reflective" day. Devastated Barbie-and-Ken-friendly homes across the country were suddenly faced with the task of explaining the breakup to their children — and finding separate toy boxes for the pair. Sunshine said he'd been barraged with e-mails from fans. Arons suggested moms and dads handle it "much like a parent may someday have to explain a divorce" and assure their little girls that Barbie and Ken would always care for each other and be friends. Cynics called the split a desperate publicity stunt by the couple's company, Mattel Inc., which has seen Barbie's popularity and revenues in the U.S. drop recently despite her numerous image makeovers and new products. But Arons brushed aside the implication that Mattel might toss Barbie out on her ear. "Mattel would never dump Barbie," she said. Barbie was holed up in her Dream House with friends and family, according to Sunshine, who also represents human Hollywood stars Ben Affleck, Justin Timberlake and Leonardo DiCaprio. It wasn't clear where Ken was staying. A statement the handsome man-doll had prepared was read at the press conference. "Barbie and I decided to spend some time apart," the statement read. "She's got a new look ... I'm confident we will always stay friends." When asked about the catalyst for the split, Arons simply said it was the "toll of the fourth movie" they starred in together — a musical due out in the fall called "Barbie as The Prince and the Pauper" — and the pressure of being in the limelight. Sunshine declined to offer specifics on the relationship's demise, and asked the press to "please, please respect their privacy." Sunshine and Arons had no comment as to whether there was another "Ken" in Barbie's life. "Barbie is actually going through something difficult," Arons said, adding that Barbie was just "a woman exercising options." But after the news conference, Mattel Girls Division Vice President Julia Jensen dished that in the upcoming months "there may be a new blush in Barbie's life." Longtime rumors surrounding Ken's androgyny and sexual orientation were quickly dismissed Thursday. Arons said the split had nothing to do with Ken's sexuality and that the couple loved each other. "He is not of mixed gender," she said. And other whisperings that Barbie and Ken are secretly sister and brother weren't even touched on. The couple — whose romance seemed so picture-perfect that other successful pairings in and out of Hollywood were frequently dubbed "Barbie and Ken" — met on the set of their first television commercial in 1961. Their relationship unfolded much like any other Hollywood romance, though it lasted quite a bit longer. They fell madly in love and quickly became joined at the hip, as the saying goes. They even worked together on several projects. It was a fairytale, really. That is, until the unhappy ending. Some said the relationship dissolved because the pressure of being in the public eye became too great — even after 43 years. Others gossiped that Ken's ambiguous sexuality and Barbie's disproportionate figure finally took their toll. Still others blamed the break on the fact that Barbie's career and popularity continued to overshadow Ken's. Then there were those who maintained that they were just a plastic couple from the beginning. Ken's publicist denied that the all-American doll guy felt overshadowed by his gorgeous doll gal. "For four decades Ken has been a real supporter of Barbie. We've all joked about it, but he really enjoyed being Mr. Barbie," Arons said. Still, the question remains whether or not Barbie's fame finally did come between the pair. "Ken played a role in every movie, but Barbie certainly was the star," Jensen added later. "But he's got strong shoulders. I wouldn't want to put words in his mouth. His official statements is that he's obviously thrilled with her success." The twosome's relationship might be over, but their troubles aren't, especially when it comes to the settlement. They'll be faced with the task of divvying up the hundreds of possessions they've amassed over the years, such as the Barbie Bubble Bath, camper, townhouse and several vehicles. As for the mansion in Malibu? "The Dream House has always been Barbie's," Arons said.

I love getting new clothes. It's so much fun to go to work (or anywhere, for that matter) in a new outfit. There's just something about the way new clothes smell and feel the first time you wear them. However, there are sometimes slight differences between the old clothes and the new clothes that can take some time to get used to. Zipper placement is a perfect example. You know how on men's shirts, the buttons close from the left and women's close from the right? Well, I would imagine the same concept would apply to zipper placement on pants. Apparently I was wrong. Most of my slacks that I wear to work have the zipper on the right, meaning the little flap that covers the zipper folds over from the left. These great new pants that I got at urlLink Filene's Basement last week are awesome - they fit well, and are incredibly comfortable (although the fitting room in the Basement is not quite what I expected - let's just say that there aren't any stalls; it's more of a communal setting). But the zipper on these oh-so-wonderful pants is located on the opposite side from where I am used to zippering. For most people, this would not be a big issue. I, however, am not most people. I can't tell you how many times I've forgotten to zip up my pants after having done my business in the stall at work. Let's say I average about 6 trips to the bathroom in a day (yes, I drink a LOT of water). And of those 6 trips yesterday, I'd say I forgot to zip up my trousers approximately 4 times. That's a 66% failure rate on remembering to zip up my pants. And you'd think that since I'm left-handed, I'd have a better time of zipping them up with the zipper on the left side. Not so, my friends. Quite a dilemma.

For those of you not in the know, a large portion of the United States is currently being overtaken by the Brood X cicada clan. Brood X, otherwise known as the 17-year clan (or, as my grandfather likes to call them, those rat-bastard-sons-of-bitches), gestates underground for 17 years, feeding on sap and tree roots. After 17 years, these suckers bore their way to the surface, leaving nice little holes in your lawn - sort of a natural aerator. After getting to the surface, they climb the nearest tree or plant, do a little molting, then do the nasty, lay some eggs and die. It's quite amazing to me how much urlLink internet media attention this phenomenon has received. I don't remember hearing this much about it last time it happened. Granted, I was only 9 years old, and the internet hadn't made it to the general public yet. Still, these suckers are nasty! Why the fascination? Maybe it's their beady red eyes. In any event, I wanted to share with you an amusing site called urlLink Cicadaville that my uncle forwarded to other members of the family. Enjoy! And keep your children indoors!!

While visiting home two and a half weeks ago, I made the mistake of walking on a wooden footbridge after it had rained. My sister was with me, and I should have taken her near spill down the steps of the bridge as a warning. But no. I could handle the wet steps. Or so I thought. About 3 seconds after Jessica nearly fell, I did what she managed to avoid. I landed right on my ass. Now, given my somewhat advanced state of intoxication, I didn't realize the extent of my injuries. In fact, the next morning, I just assumed the aching was part of the hangover that was definitely due to me. Even the dull pain that built up over the course of my nine and a half hour drive back to Boston didn't drive home that I might have done some damage to my posterior. Upon closer inspection, it turns out I had a fist-sized bruise on my right buttcheek that was the color of a dark red wine. Yummy. And man did it hurt to sit for long periods of time!! After two weeks of on-again-off-again pain, I went to the doctor this past Tuesday. He confirmed my fears - a bruised tailbone. Apparently if I'd broken it, the pain would've been unbearable. He put me on some prescription pain killers ( urlLink Ultracet - check out the website; they have a calming Flash intro that's got music and everything!), and suggested I get an ass donut. My urlLink inflatable ass donut and I are best buds for the next 4-6 weeks.
